subject: Re: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
msgSnippet: ... Ok imagine JUnit implements the counting of assertions.  You run your tests and get 90 tests, 405 assertions .  That s great, but what does this number
messageBody:
Thomas Obst wrote:

>Why then does JUnit display the number of test cases? If it is interesting to know how
>many test cases the system has passed, then it is also interesting to know how many
>asserts have made it. This is especially true if a test case is something like testMethod(),
>where the individual asserts verify that various values of the parameters to method()
>work (max, min, null, normal, etc). Sure these could all be individual test cases, but then
>it becomes difficult to see whether I really have exhaustively tested my method. Code
>coverage is not the solution. That only tells me whether what I have written, opposed to
>what I should have written, works.
>
Ok imagine JUnit implements the counting of assertions. You run your
tests and get "90 tests, 405 assertions". That's great, but what does
this number "405" tells you? And what is that better than "90 tests,
404 assertions" and worst than "90 tests, 406 assertions"? Does this
magic number "405" tell you that the "individual asserts verify that
various values of the parameters to method() work (max, min, null,
normal, etc)". Do you expect a certain ration #assertions/#tests?

How does this magic "405" tells you that you have tested what you
_should have_ written? I you don't know what you should have written, I
doubt that a simple number could tell you that...

Here is maybe a good test:

void setMyValue (int value) {
myValue = value);
}

[...]

void testMyValueWithEverything () {
for (int i=INT_MIN; i<INT_MAX; i++) {
myObject.setMyValue(i);
assertTrue(myObject.getMyValue() == i);
}
for (double j=DOUBLE_MIN; j<DOUBLE_MAX; j++) {
myObject.setMyValue(j);
assertTrue(myObject.getMyValue() == Integer(j).toInt());
}
}

you have "exhaustively tested [your] method".

The # of assertions will only give you a feeling of security. A much
better approach could be to develop a simple framework to stress-test a
component but that's not the goal of JUnit.

-Vladimir
